description:
Acomys russatus, commonly known as the golden spiny mouse, is a species of rodent belonging to the genus Acomys. It is native to parts of the Middle East, including Israel, Jordan, and the Sinai Peninsula.

The golden spiny mouse is a small, nocturnal mammal characterized by its distinctive spiny fur, which is typically golden or reddish-brown in color. This adaptation helps the animal camouflage itself in its desert and semi-desert habitats. The species has a compact, rounded body, large eyes, and relatively large ears compared to its overall size.

Acomys russatus is an omnivorous species, feeding on a variety of plant materials, such as seeds, fruits, and leaves, as well as small invertebrates. It is known to be an excellent climber, often found inhabiting rocky areas, crevices, and abandoned burrows.

The golden spiny mouse is considered a relatively common and widespread species within its range, but it faces threats from habitat loss and degradation due to human activities, such as urban development and overgrazing. It is classified as Least Concern on the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species.
